data.title: Chapter 12 The Hungarian Kingdom between the Imperial Ecclesiology of Otto III and the Pontifical Ecclesiology of Gregory VII in: Christianization in Early Medieval Transylvania
data.meta_description: Abstrsct The medieval world displays universal forms of organization. During the Middle Ages, legally speaking, independence does not exist, as all forms of public organization were part of Christianitas and the Empire. This is also the case of the Hungarian kingdom, founded at the beginning of the second millennium by the order of Emperor Otto III and with the consent of Pope Sylvester II. The study aims to highlight the main moments of the establishment of the Hungarian kingdom as a structure associated with the Empire; a structure that from the beginning employed a link/connection of political dependence on imperial and pontifical Rome, a link that was emphasized by the advance of theocracy, specific to the so-called Gregorian Reformation. The latter part of the study presents a diplomatic text from 1920 in which the Holy See states that all the privileges assumed in the Middle Ages by the Hungarian kingdom in relation to the functioning of the Catholic Church and the Christian mission from the neighbouring territories were, in fact, never granted to the Hungarian kingdom.
data.text:
Abstrsct

The medieval world displays universal forms of organization. During the Middle Ages, legally speaking, independence does not exist, as all forms of public organization were part of Christianitas and the Empire. This is also the case of the Hungarian kingdom, founded at the beginning of the second millennium by the order of Emperor Otto III and with the consent of Pope Sylvester II. The study aims to highlight the main moments of the establishment of the Hungarian kingdom as a structure associated with the Empire; a structure that from the beginning employed a link/connection of political dependence on imperial and pontifical Rome, a link that was emphasized by the advance of theocracy, specific to the so-called Gregorian Reformation. The latter part of the study presents a diplomatic text from 1920 in which the Holy See states that all the privileges assumed in the Middle Ages by the Hungarian kingdom in relation to the functioning of the Catholic Church and the Christian mission from the neighbouring territories were, in fact, never granted to the Hungarian kingdom.
